{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3494682,"name":"Ryan Du","username":"DumbChurchill","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/9f8e36/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T14:59:08.662Z","cooked":"

Now that competition season has started, I was just wondering what CAN tips you guys have so I can be ready to wire our robot. For instance, troubleshooting, general rule of thumb, constraining, what connectors to use in what scenarios, CANivore stuff, etc. Thanks y’all!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T14:59:08.662Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":233,"readers_count":232,"score":86.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483965,"topic_slug":"can-tips","display_username":"Ryan Du","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68759,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-tips/483965/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3494689,"name":"Pedro Braga","username":"predobrega","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/predobrega/{size}/211207_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T15:07:26.678Z","cooked":"

If you are going to terminate your CAN bus somewhere other than the PDH/PDP, do NOT forget to add the 120 Ω resistor at the end of the line, and to turn off the embedded resistor in the power distribution boards. This is especially important for CAN FD with the CANivore.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T15:07:36.241Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":227,"readers_count":226,"score":65.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483965,"topic_slug":"can-tips","display_username":"Pedro Braga","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-tips/483965/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3494698,"name":"","username":"LPryor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lpryor/{size}/220287_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T15:13:38.532Z","cooked":"
  • Minimize the number of connections where possible. If you have the choice of making an extension or just running a longer wire, use the longer wire.
  • Use good connectors for the CAN. Locking MOLOX or PWM with a clip are your best option. Avoid the large inline WAGOs they are tricky to get right for smaller wires and can produce issues.
  • “Every wire gets a friend every friend gets a bundle”. Secure your wires well. I recommend separating data bundles from power line bundles. Zip ties are cheap use them liberally. Wires shouldn’t move unless they have to.
  • Use cable shielding to protect your wires. For lifts I recommend using a drag chain.
  • Avoid the chompy things - things like swerve drives are notorious for eating wires.
  • Canivores are awesome if you are on the CTRE stack. I like separating the drive train from the mechanisms. It simplifies your wiring and makes debugging easier. Don’t forget the resister for your second CAN network though.
  • Errors in the code related to the CAN are often symptoms of wiring issues.
  • Keep some long strands of cable around. When you inevitably have to debug the CAN network its nice to be able to quickly isolate.

These are the lessons we learned in the last year. We used to have TONS of CAN issues now we don’t have any at all (knocks on wood)

The jacketed CAN wire from WCP should be good to help protect the CAN bus.

Hi, I was wondering how big the impact of power and can wire being run together would be. Is the impact really significant enough to warrant a separate running? I am asking since our team is experimenting with different wire organization methods.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-29T19:51:04.237Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":29.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483965,"topic_slug":"can-tips","display_username":"Ryan Du","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":55309,"username":"LPryor","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lpryor/{size}/220287_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68759,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-tips/483965/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3495902,"name":"2582","username":"chadr03","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadr03/{size}/195529_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-29T20:04:48.476Z","cooked":"

I have always been told especially in industry to try to run your power and signal wires separately, but with the tight quarters on a robot and layouts that just do not allow for separation our robots often have the signal and power wires running together we and never had any noticeable issues.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-29T20:04:48.476Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":18.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483965,"topic_slug":"can-tips","display_username":"2582","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":68759,"username":"DumbChurchill","name":"Ryan Du","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/9f8e36/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13827,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-tips/483965/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3495905,"name":"","username":"LPryor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lpryor/{size}/220287_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-29T20:07:16.449Z","cooked":"

So interference is technically possible, but lots of people do it and don’t see any problems. (Or negligible ones)

The potential for interference is directly proportional to the amount of energy being transmitted…so maybe avoid the main battery cables.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-29T20:07:16.449Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483965,"topic_slug":"can-tips","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":68759,"username":"DumbChurchill","name":"Ryan Du","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/9f8e36/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55309,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 8280, President Motor City Alliance"},"post_url":"/t/can-tips/483965/8","custom_user_title":"Mentor 8280, President Motor City Alliance","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3496197,"name":"Eric Tate","username":"MrT8","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrt8/{size}/9889_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-30T00:28:29.389Z","cooked":"

The main culprit in causing interference or “noise” on signal lines comes from being near power cables with some high frequency component - such as the cables going from the controller to the motor. These have PWM switching which has high frequency content that couples easier to the signal wires. The cables supplying DC to the motors tend to have much less high frequency content. Best practice for signal cables that must go near power cables is to cross at 90 degrees if possible and avoid long runs in parallel.

Constrain and strain relieve. Don’t let can wires dangle anywhere. Protect those CAN wires with your life

Also +1 for CANivore. We have one for our drivetrain. Helps keep you moving if your other CAN network gets broken
